English Bio:
Fortunatus II, also Fortunatus of Grado, more rarely of Trieste (* in Trieste, † March 12 825 or 826 in Rome), was from 777 Bishop of Treviso, from 806 to 810 of Pula and from 803/810 to about 820 Patriarch from Grado. He is considered in the struggle between the Franconian and the Byzantine emperors as an exponent of the pro-Frankish party. According to Roberto Cessi and Gherardo Ortalli, the patriarchal survey was an expression of distrust of the doge of Venice, with the aim of reversing their pro-Byzantine orientation. Simone Dellagiacoma, he was considered the greatest of the 60 Patriarchs of Grado, who ruled between 725 and 1451. [2] Either because he joined a conspiracy against the Doge of Venice, or because he supported Ljudewit, a possibly early Croatian regional ruler against the Franks, he had to flee to Constantinople. From there he returned to 824/25, but died on the way to Rome or in the city. He was buried there as abbot of Moyenmoutier.

In 777, Fortunatus, born in Trieste, was elevated to Bishop of Treviso, whom the Franks had recently conquered by the Lombards and made the capital of their margraviate Verona. Fortunatus sought successfully in the course of the following years, the alliance with the Franks under Charlemagne. It can not be confirmed, as it is called in a 12th century commentary in the oldest patriarchal list, a survey of the Bishop of Trieste.

After his uncle John, the Patriarch of Grado and the Fortunatus predecessor in office, 802 was murdered at the behest of the same Venetian doge John, Fortunatus was his successor. He settled in 803 by Emperor Charles and Pope Leo III. confirm in his office. He received the pallium on March 23, 803.

First, he tried to overthrow the two Doge John and his son Mauritius (II) to take revenge on the murder of his predecessor, but the plan failed and he had to flee together with his relative and ally Obelerius to Treviso to to place it under the protection of the Franks. After the two Dogen 804 had finally been overthrown with Franconian support, joined Fortunatus' confidant Obelerius the office of doge. At the Frankish court Fortunatus received a diploma in March 803, in which he was granted immunity in the face of his merits, as well as his clerics and followers. In a diploma, possibly issued at the same time, he also received tax exemption for transit in any place in the empire for four of his ships. He should soon have become economically independent. In addition, he received the Abbey Moyenmoutier as Benefizium. During his absence, Grado was taken by the Dukat Venice. The Franks could hardly accept this.

Although Karl also promoted the church in north-eastern Italy, there were rivalries such as those between Aquileia and Grado. This was true for Istria, where Charles wanted to strengthen the rights of Aquileia, on the other hand, Fortunatus was important for the common struggle against the pro-Byzantine groups in the Upper Adriatic. Therefore, in 803 he turned to Fortunatus as "Venetiarum et Istriensium patriarcha", which he legitimized his Obodienzforderungen with a view to the Istrian bishoprics, especially Pola. Fortunatus went after the Venetian military strike to Istria, where he 804 together with five bishops and other representatives from his birthplace Trieste, as well as Istria, the decision of Risano, initiated the Placito del Risano. The Patriarch and his entourage presented the royal messengers (Missi Dominici) Emperor Charles their demands, which were largely recognized. The region was granted extensive duty-free status, and - which was an uncommon right in the Frankish feudal system - permission to regulate its own internal affairs and to choose its own bishops and officials.

805 had to leave Fortunatus Grado for the first time, and he was replaced by the deacon John, who has received an inscription in Grado. It reads: "John siquidem patriarcha, qui per quattuor annorum spacia Gradensem sedem vivente pastore usurpavit, sinodali censura depositu est". [4] The patriarch therefore usurped the patriarchal chair for four years, ie until 809.

As part of this "usurpation" Fortunatus was raised on the initiative of Charles, who turned to the Pope, the Bishop of Pula in Istria, an office that he completed to 810. Since Fortunatus formally continued to hold the office of the Patriarch of Grado, Pope Leo III. his appointment as Bishop of Pola first off. Only after the agreement to relinquish the bishop's chair in Pola, as soon as he could resume his seat in Grado, which he had "propter persecutionem Grecorum seu Veneticorum", confirmed the Pope Fortunatus in his office as Bishop of Pola. Karl is said to have desired, as a spiritual father, after a reference to the author of the Chronica de singulis patriarch Nove Aquileie, Fortunatus. [5] The Pope, however, admonished the emperor not to listen to the apologists of Fortunatus, for his whole behavior was unworthy of an archbishop, and the said apologists had been corrupted. This accusation probably confirms the reclamation of goods by the successor of Fortunatus, the patriarch Venerius, who had bequeathed the said goods to his nephew Domenico.

In 810 King Pippin of Italy, one of the sons of Charlemagne, conquered a number of places in the lagoon of Venice. Although the Venetians had successfully resisted the Franconian invasion and Obelerio had to resign from his doge by virtue of his alliance with the Franks, Fortunatus was able to return to Grado. Karl recognized 810 that the lagoon belonged to the eastern empire. Fortunatus' ambitious plans lost their foundation, even though a source dating back to 819 calls him "Patriarch of the Church of Aquileia and Grado." In the following years, the cultural influence of the Franks, as can be seen in works of art of the time, grew in the Patriarchate Grado.

In 815, at the instigation of Fortunatus, Charles' son Louis the Pious renewed the right of the Istrian region to raise its own bishops and officials. As late as 820, Fortunatus participated in a conspiracy to overthrow the new doge of Venice, the Agnello Particiaco. The plot, however, flew open and Fortunatus was banished; as the Venetian chronicler Johannes Diaconus claims, after 27 years of rule. His office as Patriarch of Grado took over the Abbot of San Servolo as John V.

According to Franconian sources Fortunatus was overthrown for quite different reasons. He is said to have supported a rebellion in 821 in Pannonia inferior under the leadership of the Ljudewit, whose nucleus was the Croatian Sisak. There was a war, which the Franks ended victoriously; Constantinople was probably unable to support the rebellion. [6] This victory can also be archaeologically detected, because in the west of Croatia disappeared an idiosyncratic archaeological culture with relations to Bohemia. After a request to go to the imperial court, Fortunatus traveled to Istria to pretend to obedience - after all, he was obliged to obedience to the emperor as abbot of Moyenmoutier - but soon fled to Zara, ie to the Byzantine empire. The local Prefect of the province of Dalmatia immediately sent the refugees to Constantinople. Either the Treaty of Aachen from 812 had led to a change in relations between the Franks and Byzantines in the area Grado -Istrien, or Emperor Louis had given up the until 814 led by his father's policy of protection. Fortunatus stayed until 824 in the Byzantine capital. Whether he used the stay, about which nothing else is known, to acquire relics or ornaments for his Gradeser church, is not to be proven from the narrative sources.

Fortunatus returned to the Frankish court with a group of Byzantine ambassadors, probably to return to patriarchal office. But Ludwig referred the deposed patriarch to Rome. According to the chronicler of Moyenmoutier, he died in 826 during this stay in Rome, while he finished his life after John Diaconus in Frankish territory. The said Franconian sources are not interested in Fortunatus since he was sent from Ludwig to Rome. In December 824, the patriarch stayed in his Frankish monastery Moyenmoutier. A chronicler of the early 11th century, who in his Liber de sancti Hidul fi successoribus on the successors of St. Idulfo or Hydulphe Moyenmoutier († 707) writes: "Mira autem dispositione divinitatis repertus est ibidem Fortunatus patriarcha venerabilis, qui gratia salutandi famosum principem, from Hierosalimis peregre disgressus erat", so Fortunatus had returned from Jerusalem. The same chronicler also reports how Fortunatus sent an embassy on behalf of Emperor Charles to Harun ar-Rashid a few years earlier, although it remains unclear whether he himself may have participated in this legation.

After the necrosis of the monastery Moyenmoutier Fortunatus died on March 12, probably at the latest in the year 825 or 826, also the 26th February is given. He was buried in the monastery near the altar of Gregory the Great. In a sort of letter, possibly from the Byzantine exile he sent to his clerics in Grado, which resembles a will, Fortunatus lists his contributions to the Graden church and expresses his hope for a speedy return. The document is not dated. Meanwhile, this source is seen more as the excerpt of a court record in which the patriarch tried to prioritize his merit while being accused of robbing the Grades church. [9]

An archaeological find speaks for a stay Fortunatus' in Jerusalem. During the excavations at the Grades church S. Maria delle Grazie came in 1925 on a ciborium an inscription that was highly fragmented (Grado, Museo Lapidario). Deciphering their meaning did not succeed for decades, especially since some letters are missing, and the subsequent arrangement of the fragments did not yield meaningful text. Maurizio Buora proposed in 2017 as a reading "GLORIO (sis) TEMPORIB (u) S TER B - caput - EATI M [VN] HE (a) Q (uae) E SION [DVX] IT SE (cum)" [tul] IT "is conceivable. "Sion" stands for "Jerusalem" (pp. 36-38), the inscription thus reminds of the said stay in Jerusalem and the "munera" that Fortunatus brought with him.

This is significant insofar as it is known that Harun ar-Rashid sent a piece of the Cross of Christ to the Frankish Emperor, which Helena, the mother of Constantine the Great, had received. Also in Grado is a piece of the said cross, and thus one of the most important relics. Although the container is much younger, it may be a relic that Fortunatus had procured. The temporal proximity to the robbery of the relics of the evangelist Markus in the year 829 from Alexandria makes this scenario, according to Maurizio Buora, even more probable. In addition, the assumption suggests that Fortunatus wanted to prepare with these foundations to the Grades Church his return.

Pietro Marcello noted in 1502 in his later translated into the Volgare under the title Vite de'prencipi di Vinegia translated work, that it was "Mauritio Galbaio" succeeded, which until then no one had managed to make his son his successor. Marcello reproaches John above all for his behavior towards the patriarch Fortunatus and the subsequent military intervention Pippins. Fortunatus, who had to flee after his conspiracy against the Doges had flown, had spoken badly to the Venetians to Karl and so upset him ("lo attizzò in tal modo") that he had given his son the said command.

Francesco Sansovino (1512-1586) believes in his Opus Delle cose notabili della città di Venetia, Libri II published in Venice in 1587, to a congiura led by Obelerio and Fortunatus, the nephew of the murdered Patriarch of Grado, who " i dogi "(the 'Doge') forced 804 to flee. [11]

In the translation of the Historia Veneta of Alessandro Maria Vianoli, which appeared in Nuremberg in 1686 under the title The Venetian Hertzogen Life / Government, and Death / From the First Paulutio Anafesto to the itzt-reigning Marcum Antonium Justiniani, [12] the Patriarch John of Grado, who had fallen from a tower, was "a very sincere and honest man" whose assassination meant that the two exponents Fortunatus and Obelerio, "the then guild master of Malamocco," began to "rebel against them". In doing so, Fortunatus has "made a fortune to avenge the unbilished and innocent death of his ancestor" (p. 67). But the conspiracy was exposed - "because they were not attacked the best / nor with the necessary secrecy ... been linked" - and Fortunatus and Obelerio had to flee with their supporters.

Johann Friedrich LeBret knew from 1769 in his political history of the Republic of Venice, that after Obelerius had been chosen by the Treviso fled supporters of Fortunatus and remaining in Venice, anti-dynastically thinking "nobles" to the "Duke", the mere rumor of this proclamation "," John and Morizen so timid "have made that they are determined to flee. Like the Doges, the bishop "Christoph", who was appointed by the two Doge, fled to "France," and was never allowed to return. John, while still in office, tried to neutralize the suspicious Pippin by sending "Nicephorus," the East Emperor Nikephorus I, a fleet to "hold Pipin in check" (p. 123). Obelerius, according to LeBret, first came to Venice after learning about the flight of the doge. The driver of the coup attempt, which had failed at the time, was Fortunatus, who felt that he was justified in seeking revenge for the death of his predecessor (p. 122). In a letter from Pope Leo to Charlemagne, the pontiff states that Fortunatus "sends himself better to a court than to the care of the soul". "Fortunatus, the troubled Patriarch of Grado, who played such a masterful role in destroying the state, destroying his role, came back from France and brought with him the fleeting Bishop Christopher of Olivolo." LeBret does not seem to explain that why he brought Christopher with him, although his predecessor had not wanted to consecrate him, and although he had been a supporter of the overthrown Doge. "These two clerics must therefore have entered into such a close friendship through a special connection, of which we find no trace." The author surmises that Karl himself may have reached a balance between the clerics. When Fortunatus, "a man full of intrigues," had to flee from the fleet of Niketas and thus finally flee, "Thus the state was liberated from a prelate whose greatest joy was when the fatherland was put into the utmost disarray." 125). Finally, the author mentions that after the death of his benefactor Charles, Fortunatus fell out of favor with his overly self-contained policy, especially when he supported "Lint-witus," whom he "gave much encouragement," and "sent many skilled workers," whose he used to fortify his castles and cities "(p. 140). "But the matter was betrayed by one of his priests to K. Ludwig, who therefore called him to his court." Fortunatus traveled to Zara after a detour via Istria, where he sought Byzantine protection. As a result, Fortunatus, who had already incited Karl ("knowing from experience what this man had blown for a fire at the court of Charlemagne"), was deposed. At Fortunatus' place stood the abbot of the "Monastery of the H. Servulus, John". The new Emperor Michael sent the fled to Constantinople Fortunatus with an embassy to Emperor Ludwigs court. Louis sent him to Rome with the legation, accompanied by some of his men, but Fortunatus died en route.

Samuele Romanin believes in the first volume of his ten-volume opus Storia documentata di Venezia, [14] Fortunatus had begun a "vendetta" to avenge the death of his predecessor, the author follows Johannes Diaconus. According to this Fortunatus especially the Obelerius, the tribunes of Malamocco, but also numerous other men to accomplices ("complici", p. 136). In the interpretation of the negotiations between Karl and Nikephoros Romanin follows the statements of Andrea Dandolo, according to which all of northern Italy should go to the Frankish kingdom, while Venice and the cities of Dalmatia, because they were loyal to Byzantium ("costanti nella sincera devozione all'imperio orientale" ), should remain with the East, as its southern Italian areas. [15] Also follows the author Andrea Dandolo, who describes how Fortunatus incites Charlemagne by reporting that the Venetians were completely attached to Byzantium - qui Constantinopolitano Imperio totaliter adhaerere videbantur ", he quotes Dandolo - and they had murdered his predecessor (p ). The Doge fled, with Father John went to Mantua, his son Mauritius but found an overpowering opponent at the imperial court. On the other hand, Fortunatus (this contradiction does not dissolve Romanin) recommended the bishop "Cristoforo". Even when 'his friend' Obelerius was elected Doge, he could not dare to bring him back to the patriarchal chair because of his friendly attitude. In addition, there had been renewed fights between Jesolans and Equilians. The leading families are said to have moved from Equilio and Grado to Malamocco. Meanwhile, Fortunatus was returning from Campalto. First, however, he sat down with the support of Charles on Istria, where he became Bishop of Pola. Together with Cristoforo, who again became Bishop of Olivolo, he operated the Franconian cause after returning to Grado. With the fleet of the Niketas the power relations changed again. Another Cristoforo became Bishop of Olivolo, Fortunatus fled to the Frankish kingdom. With the Treaty of Aachen Charles recognized the special role of Venice and Fortunatus was able to return to Grado (p. 158). But in 820 the Patriarch stumbled upon another attempt to overthrow a doge. He went to the Frankish kingdom, where he died, or, as others say, in Rome.

August Friedrich Gfrörer († 1861) believed in his 1872 posthumous history of Venice from its founding to the year 1084, [16] Fortunatus had also expressly submit to the bishoprics of Istria, which had been withdrawn from the Patriarchate 771 by the Lombards. At the same time, as Andrea Dandolo observed, Karl did not consider Lake Veneto as part of his kingdom (p. 97). According to Gfrörer, this fits in with the Franke's "Eginhard": "In 803, the patriarch Fortunatus, coming from the land of the Greeks, appeared at the Frankish court." Fortunatus also complained to Gfrörer that the Venetians had murdered his predecessor, and that "that the Venetians had made the decision to adhere entirely to the realm of Constantinople." In Treviso, his supporter Obelerius was elected Doge, who came from Malamocco, "as the center of the Lombard party, which by the power of circumstances gradually turned into a Frankish one since the fall of King Desiderius" (pp. Fortunatus and Christopher remained "in the village of Cypriano (near Mestre), for they were barred from entering the islands." By cunning he brought another Johann, the bishop of Olivolo in his power, but he was able to escape and complained to the doge about his mistreatment. Nevertheless, Fortunatus succeeded first in enforcing Christoph again in Olivolo, and then returning to Grado himself (p. 103). Until then, Obelerius had probably been unable to enforce the return of his ally, either because of the Greek party - Gfrörer sees only this party and the Franconian party at work - or because of enemies from the Frankish party itself. Consequently, it was Fortunatus who made the promise to be supported, namely by the pro-Byzantine groups, first brought the former opponent Christoph back, and then again take his Doge's seat.

After the posthumous editor Dr. John Baptist of White the translator into Italian, Pietro Pinton, had forbidden to annotate the statements Gfrörers in the translation, appeared Pintons Italian version in the Archivio Veneto in the annual volumes XII to XVI. However, Pinton had enforced that he was allowed to publish his own account in the said Archivio Veneto, which, however, appeared only in 1883. Although Pinton often came to entirely different, less speculative results in his research than Gfrörer, but he largely agreed with the author in connection with the first dog dynasty. But Pinton believes that Gfrörer had been threatened by the Franks by claiming that at the time of the assassination of the bishop almost all the land over which the two doge ruled. [17] He told Gfrörer that he came through a wrong chronology to inaccurate conclusions about the motivations of those involved. This is proved, for example, by the fact that he wrote that Andrea Dandolo copied from Paulus Diaconus, but after that he only followed the doctrine of the Doge, without Gfrörer perceiving the differences between the two authors (pp. 40-42). , Pinton also does not believe that under the aegis of the Franks there was a conspiracy followed by the escape of Fortunatus, for after the seizure of power by Obelerius he was hardly refused a return without reason (p. 53), and above all Obelerius According to Gfrörer, one of the heads of the Fortunatus franc conspiracy, assisted by a fleet to recapture Dalmatia, and his brother Beatus was given the title of ipat, a consul (p. 55). The Byzantine fleet also anchored beneath it in the lagoon. Overall, although Pinton recognized the links between Fortunatus and the Franks, Gfrörer misinterpreted the composition of the 804 subversionists, or rather their role in the dispute between the empires.

In 1861, Francesco Zanotto believes in his Il Palazzo ducale di Venezia that Fortunatus had a "vendetta" against the Galbaii, a bloodthirst that was finally crowned with success. At the behest of Charlemagne, this act led both Doge into exile. [18]

For Heinrich Kretschmayr Fortunatus was "a personal favorite of Charlemagne," he was "violent, ambitious, unsteady, bitter by the murder of relatives, personally threatened by reprisals of the Greek party." [19] He was the champion of a Frankish party, but also of those who felt "indignation" "about the violence of Grado". He fled with his followers to Treviso, "then hurried alone to the court of Charlemagne to Selz". Kretschmayr assumes that the "haughty refusal he received from his alliance claim by Emperor Nikephoros" was the reason he supported Fortunatus in his effort to overthrow the "faithful Duces". Fortunatus received not only the monastery Moyenmoutier and the said trade freedoms, but also the commitment to subordination of the Istrian dioceses under Grado. In 804 Obelerius overthrew the pro-Byzantine Doge and raised his brother Beatus to fellow-doer. Rhetorically, the author asks: "Was this revolution of 804 the victory of a Frankish party in Veneto?" "Even in 805, both Duces decided to strict submission to the Frankish kingdom" and "In Reich division law of 6 February 806 Venetia, Istria and Dalmatia assigned to King Pippin's shares "(p. 55 f.). A Byzantine fleet appeared in the spring of 807, Obelerius surrendered, the Greeks took Beatus, Christopher of Olivolo, "the protégé Fortunats," and the tribunes Felix as hostages, "one of the chief conspirators of 804". Fortunatus had already withdrawn from the rumor of the approaching fleet by fleeing to the Frankish kingdom of capture. Pippin, of whom Kretschmayr assumes that he not only attempted the conquest of Venice, but successfully brought it to a conclusion, at first agreed with Niketas on a peace valid until August 808. Beatus returned, "trained in Greek interest", and the third brother, Valentinus, was also raised to doge. Again a fleet from Constantinople appeared in 809, but failed to conquer Comacchio. The withdrawal of this fleet Pippin now used the decisive attack on the lagoon, in revenge for "the fall of 807 and the malicious cross-rubbings of 809" - the Doge had brought the Frankish-Byzantine negotiations to failure. After "Heracliana in the north, Brondolo, Chioggia, Pelestrina and Albiola in the south", after fierce fighting at Albiola "also Malamocco fell - there is no doubt about that". After Kretschmayr also the doge prisoners Pippins were. Rialto, however, might not be conquered, perhaps Pippin's army even suffered a defeat. Otherwise, the author believes that Rialto has been conquered, "despite all the Venetian fables". Venice remained Franconian, even when another Byzantine fleet appeared that could only fend off a Frankish attack on Dalmatia. During this time, Fortunatus returned to Grado, before or after the Treaty of Aachen. One and a half centuries later, according to Kretschmayr, "Constantine Porphyrogennetos" reports only two events from Venice's history, namely the escape from Attila and the conquest by Pippin (p. 58).

In his History of Venice, John Julius Norwich, who largely ignores the reception history, [20] emphasizes that Fortunatus, "more bitterly opposed to the regime of Galbaii, than even his uncle had been," immediately fled to the Frankish kingdom. Under the alleged leadership of Obelerius, the opposition gathered in Treviso, who finally made the breakthrough in 804. But now there were fights within the lagoon, especially between Heraclea and Malamocco, the new regiment came into a similar situation as the Galbaii before. But now Fortunatus appeared, "fresh from the court of Charlemagne with an offer". This offer consisted in the reinstatement of his person and the recognition of Franconian sovereignty over the lagoon, in return, the two Doge remained under Frankish protection safely in office. After Norwich neither Obelerio nor his brother Beatus had sympathy for the Franks, but the two brothers now had little choice. Therefore they made the Christmas in 805 the emperor in Aachen the Homagium. Obelerius even went so far as to find a wife from the women of the court who was for Norwich the "first dogaressa known to history".

Name: Giovanni VIII. Morosini oder Marcello Administrator
Lambert, O.F.M. auch Bischof von Aquino
Reginbrand
German Bio: Reginbrand (‚Ä† 988) war der erste Bischof von Aarhus.  Er empfing 948 durch Erzbischof Adaldag von Hamburg-Bremen mit ausdr√ºcklicher Erlaubnis von Papst Agapitus II. die Bischofsweihe. Mit zwei weiteren Bisch√∂fen neuer Bist√ºmer, n√§mlich Hored (Oredo) in Schleswig und Leofdag in Ribe, nahm er am 7. Juni 948 an der Universalsynode von Ingelheim teil. Dies bezeichnete einen bedeutenden Fortschritt in der Geschichte der d√§nischen Kirche, denn von nun an konnten alle liturgischen Feiern von einheimischen Bisch√∂fen durchgef√ºhrt werden.  Nach Reginbrands Tod wurden die drei Di√∂zesen in J√ºtland gemeinsam verwaltet. Erst um 1060 wurde Aarhus wieder Bischofssitz.
English Bio:
Reginbrand († 988 ) was the first bishop of Aarhus .

He received the episcopal consecration in 948 by Archbishop Adaldag of Hamburg-Bremen with the express permission of Pope Agapitus II . With two other bishops of new dioceses, namely Hored (Oredo) in Schleswig and Leofdag in Ribe , he participated in the Universal Synod of Ingelheim on 7 June 948 . This marked a significant step forward in the history of the Danish church, since from now on all liturgical celebrations were performed by local bishops.

After Reginbrand's death, the three dioceses in Jutland were jointly administered. It was not until around 1060 that Aarhus became bishop again.

Name: Tyge I. gegen den vom Erzbischof favorisierten Arnfast
Peder Jensen Lodehat
German Bio: Peder Jensen Lodehat, latinisiert Petrus Johannis Lodehat (‚Ä† 19. Oktober 1416) war ein d√§nischer Bischof und enger Vertrauter der Regentin Margarethe¬†I.  Seine Eltern, sein Geburtsort und sein Geburtsdatum sind nicht bekannt.  Er geh√∂rte einem Adelsgeschlecht aus Seeland an. Dieses f√ºhrte in seinem Wappen einen M√§nnerkopf mit einer runden Kopfbedeckung √§hnlich einem Judenhut. Daher stammte auch ihr Beiname, den die Familienmitglieder selbst nie benutzten. Peder Jensen wird das erste Mal im November 1375 erw√§hnt, als Margarethe¬†I. den Kanoniker Peder Jensen unmittelbar nach dem Tod seines Vaters im Dom zu Roskilde mit Landbesitz in Udby belehnt. 1382 verschaffte sie ihm das Bistum V√§xj√∂. Es geh√∂rte zu ihrer Politik, die Bist√ºmer mit gut ausgebildeten M√§nnern des niederen Adels zu besetzen, die ihr dann treu ergeben waren.[1] Ihr politisches Ziel war es, eine m√∂glichst breite loyale Unterst√ºtzung f√ºr die Wahl ihres Sohnes Olav zum K√∂nig zu gewinnen.[2]  Als 1386 das Bistum Aarhus vakant wurde, wurde Peder Jensen dorthin versetzt. Im folgenden Jahr beteiligte er sich als d√§nischer Reichsrat an der Wahl Margarethes¬†I. zum ‚Äûbevollm√§chtigten Vormund des Reiches‚Äú. Von da an blieb er bis zu ihrem Tod als Freund und Ratgeber an ihrer Seite. 1395 √ºbernahm er das Bistum Roskilde, wurde Reichskanzler und verwahrte das Reichssiegel.  Er nahm 1395 an wichtigen Unionstreffen in Helsingborg und auf Lindholmen und im folgenden Jahr an der Zusammenkunft mit Gerhard¬†VI. in Assens teil, als die Frage der Lehnsverpflichtungen der Schaumburger gegen√ºber dem neugew√§hlten K√∂nig Erich erstmals aufkam. 1397 besiegelte er mit anderen den Unionsvertrag von Kalmar. Er unterst√ºtzte mit den Mitteln seines Bistums Margarethe auch finanziell. 1401 hatte er gegen diese eine Darlehensforderung von mindestens 40.000 L√ºbische Mark und bekam Skan√∏r und Falsterbo mit den dazugeh√∂renden Zolleinnahmen als Pfand, das 1407 wieder eingel√∂st wurde. Er k√ºmmerte sich besonders um das von Margarethe gegr√ºndete Nonnenkloster der Dominikaner der Heiligen Agnethe (Agnes) in Gaun√∏. Er wurde auch damit betraut, die gro√üen finanziellen Stiftungen Margaretes f√ºr Kirchen, Kl√∂ster und Arme in allen drei Reichen zu verwalten. Im Juli 1413 f√§llte er das Urteil auf dem Lehnsgericht in Nyborg gegen den holsteinischen Adel und erkl√§rte die Familie von Heinrich III. von Schauenburg-Holstein des Lehens von Schleswig wegen Rechtsbruchs f√ºr verlustig.  Neben seinem politischen Wirken setzte er sich auch f√ºr die kirchlichen Belange ein. Im Dom zu Aarhus stiftete er einen Altar zum Heiligen Kreuz und im Dom zu Roskilde baute er eine Kapelle, die dem Heiligen Siegfried, dem Schutzpatron von V√§xj√∂, geweiht war.  Der Artikel beruht im Wesentlichen auf dem Artikel von Thelma Jexlev, Henry Bruun.
English Bio:
Peder Jensen Lodehat , Latinized Petrus Johannis Lodehat († October 19, 1416 ) was a Danish bishop and close confidant of the regent Margarethe I.

His parents, birthplace and date of birth are unknown.

He belonged to a noble family from Zealand . This resulted in his coat of arms a men's head with a round headgear similar to a Jew's hat . Hence her nickname , which the family members never used themselves. Peder Jensen is mentioned for the first time in November 1375, when Margarethe I. the canon Peder Jensen immediately after the death of his father in Roskilde Cathedral with land ownership in Udby . In 1382 she procured for him the diocese Växjö . It was part of her policy to occupy the dioceses with well-educated men of the lower nobility , who were then devoted to her.[1] Their political goal was the widest possible loyal support for the election of her son Olav winning king. [2]

When the diocese of Aarhus became vacant in 1386 , Peder Jensen was transferred there. The following year he participated as a Danish Reichsrat in the election of Margarethes I as the "authorized guardian of the Reich". From then on he remained at her side as a friend and counselor until her death. In 1395 he took over the diocese of Roskilde , became Chancellor and kept the imperial seal.

He took part in important union meetings in Helsingborg and Lindholmen in 1395 and in the following year at the meeting with Gerhard VI. participated in Assens , as the question of the Lenten obligations of the Schaumburger against the newly elected King Erich first came up. In 1397 he sealed with others the Treaty of Kalmar. He supported with the means of his diocese Margarethe also financially. In 1401 he had against this a loan claim of at least 40,000 Lübische Mark and got Skanør and Falsterbowith the associated customs revenue as a pledge, which was redeemed in 1407. He took special care of the nunnery founded by Margaret of the Dominicans of Saint Agnethe ( Agnes ) in Gaunø. He was also entrusted with managing Margaret's large financial foundations for churches, monasteries, and poor people in all three kingdoms . In July 1413 he pronounced the judgment on the Lehnsgericht in Nyborg against the Holstein nobility and declared the family of Henry III. of Schauenburg-Holstein of the fief of Schleswig because of breaking law for lost.

In addition to his political work, he also campaigned for church matters. In Aarhus Cathedral he donated an altar to the Holy Cross and in Roskilde Cathedral he built a chapel dedicated to Saint Siegfried, patron saint of Växjö.

Name: Erland
German Bio: Erland von den F√§r√∂ern (aus Bergen; ‚Ä† 13. Juni 1308 ebenda; f√§r√∂isch Erlendur, norwegisch Erlend) war 1269 bis 1308 Bischof in Kirkjub√∏ur, F√§r√∂er.  Erlendur war Lehrer und Domherr in Bergen, als er im Januar 1269 zum Bischof der F√§r√∂er geweiht wurde. Er spielte nicht nur in kirchlicher, sondern auch in politischer Hinsicht eine bedeutende Rolle auf den F√§r√∂ern und in Norwegen. Er war beispielsweise einer der sieben Bisch√∂fe, welche die Kr√∂nung und Vereidigung von Erik Magnusson am 25. Juli 1280 in Bergen √ºberwachten.  Erlendur hatte seinen Sitz im alten Bauernhof Kirkjub√∏argar√∞ur und lie√ü nebenan die Magnuskathedrale bauen. 1298 schrieb er zusammen mit Lagmann Sigurd von Shetland im Auftrag von Herzog H√•kon Magnusson das √§lteste bekannte Dokument der F√§r√∂er, den Schafsbrief.  M√∂glicherweise war Erlendur auch bei H√•kon Magnussons Kr√∂nung zum K√∂nig H√•kon V. am 1. November 1299 in Nidaros, doch dar√ºber existieren keine Dokumente. Erst am 5. Dezember 1305 taucht Erlendur wieder auf als Beistand bei der Weihe des Domherren Arne Sigurdsson zum Bischof von Bergen. An dieser Zeremonie nahm auch K√∂nig H√•kon teil. Erlends Position kommt auch dadurch zum Ausdruck, dass er einer der sechzehn Geistlichen war, die am 10. Dezember 1305 einen Erlass des K√∂nigs gegenzeichneten, in dem dieser unter anderem seiner Gemahlin Eufemia von R√ºgen die Insel Bygd√∏y bei Oslo schenkte. Danach taucht er noch in weiteren Dokumenten prominenter Zeitgenossen auf.  Sp√§ter verschlechterte sich das Verh√§ltnis von Bischof Erlendur zu K√∂nig H√•kon, indem gegenseitig schwere Vorw√ºrfe erhoben wurden. Insbesondere wurde ihm vorgeworfen, auf den F√§r√∂ern alle Steuern und den ganzen Grund und Boden einzuziehen. Letztlich scheint Erlendur (und mit ihm die Kirche) erfolgreich gewesen zu sein, denn nie zuvor besa√ü die Kirche auf den F√§r√∂ern so viel Macht und Land ‚àí doch die F√§ringer begehrten auf. Die Legende sagt, dass Erlendur bei einem Kampf in der Domkirche zu Kirkjub√∏ur get√∂tet wurde, als in einer Art B√ºrgerkrieg die Bewohner des Nordens der F√§r√∂er, auf deren Seite er stand, denen des S√ºdens unterlegen waren. Sehr viel wahrscheinlicher ist aber, dass er die F√§r√∂er verlassen musste wegen seiner wachsenden Unbeliebtheit als gieriger Steuereintreiber.  Ein Brief seines Freundes Bischof Arne von Bergen vom 22. Juni 1308 an dessen Kollegen auf Sk√•holt (Island) und Gr√∂nland deutet darauf hin, dass Erlendur am 13. Juni 1308 keineswegs in Kirkjub√∏ur starb, sondern wahrscheinlich in Bergen. Nach Erlends Tod gab es die n√§chsten vier bis f√ºnf Jahre keinen Bischof auf den F√§r√∂ern, weil sich Arne von Bergen und Erzbischof J√∏rund von Nidaros nicht auf einen Nachfolger einigen konnten. Am Ende setzte sich J√∏runds Vorschlag nach Einschaltung von Erzbischof Nikolaus von Uppsala durch, und Lodin von Borgund wurde Bischof der F√§r√∂er.  Angeblich ist Erlendur in Kirkjub√∏ur begraben. 1420 soll der f√§r√∂ische Bischof Jon der Deutsche Erlends Leiche exhumiert haben, weil es Anzeichen daf√ºr gab, dass er heiliggesprochen werden sollte. Angeblich wurde ein Runenstein gefunden, der in lateinischer Sprache eine Lobpreisung auf Erlendur gewesen sein soll und davon berichtete, dass seine Domkirche niederbrannte, weswegen er sie in Stein wieder aufbauen lie√ü (den Magnusdom).  Eine Skulptur von Erlendur steht in der Westfront des Nidarosdoms in Trondheim, Norwegen.
English Bio:
Erland from the Faroe Islands (from Bergen , † June 13, 1308 ibidem, Faroese Erlendur , Norwegian Erlend ) was from 1269 to 1308 bishop in Kirkjubøur , Faroe Islands .

Erlendur was a teacher and canon in Bergen, when he was consecrated bishop of the Faroe Islands in January 1269. He played a significant role not only in church but also in politics in the Faroes and in Norway. He was, for example, one of the seven bishops who supervised the coronation and swearing-in of Erik Magnusson on July 25, 1280 in Bergen.

Erlendur had its seat in the old farm Kirkjubøargar_ur and built next to the Magnus Cathedral . In 1298 he wrote together with Lagmann Sigurd of Shetland on behalf of Duke Håkon Magnusson the oldest known document of the Faroe Islands, the sheep letter .

It is possible that Erlendur was also at Håkon Magnusson's coronation to King Håkon V. on November 1, 1299 in Nidaros , but there are no documents about it. Only on December 5, 1305 Erlendur reappears as aiding the consecration of the canons Arne Sigurdsson to the Bishop of Bergen. King Håkon also participated in this ceremony. Erlend's position is also expressed by the fact that he was one of the sixteen clergymen who countersigned a decree of the king on December 10, 1305, in which he, among others, gave his wife Eufemia of Rügen the island of Bygdøy near Oslo. Then he appears in other documents of prominent contemporaries.

Later, the relationship between Bishop Erlendur and King Håkon worsened by heavy accusations. In particular, he was accused of collecting all taxes and all the land in the Faroe Islands. Ultimately, Erlendur (and with him the church) seems to have been successful, because never before had the church in the Faroe Islands so much power and land - but the Faroese coveted on. Legend has it that Erlendur was killed in a fight in the church at Kirkjubøur when, in a kind of civil war, the inhabitants of the north of the Faroe Islands, on whose side he stood, were inferior to those of the south. Much more likely, however, is that he had to leave the Faroe Islands because of his growing unpopularity as a greedy tax collector.

A letter from his friend Bishop Arne von Bergen of 22 June 1308 to his colleagues on Skåholt (Iceland) and Greenland indicates that Erlendur died on 13 June 1308 not at all in Kirkjubøur, but probably in Bergen. After Erlend's death, there was no bishop in the Faroe Islands for the next four to five years, because Arne von Bergen and Archbishop Jørund of Nidaros could not agree on a successor. In the end, Jørund's proposal prevailed after the intervention of Archbishop Nicholas of Uppsala , and Lodin of Borgund became Bishop of the Faroe Islands.

Allegedly, Erlendur is buried in Kirkjubøur. In 1420 the Faroese bishop Jon is said to have exhumed the German prisoner's body because there were signs that he should be canonized. Allegedly, a rune stone was found, which was said to be a praise to Erlendur in Latin and reported that his cathedral burned down, so he had them rebuilt in stone (the Magnus Cathedral).

A sculpture by Erlendur stands in the western front of the Nidaros dome in Trondheim , Norway.

Name: Jens Riber, erster lutherischer und letzter Bischof
German Bio: Jens Gregersen Riber oder Jens Gregoriussen Riber oder Jens Gregerss√∏n Riber (* 1480 (?) in Ribe, D√§nemark; ‚Ä† 9. August 1571 in Stavanger, Norwegen) war der erste lutherische Bischof auf den F√§r√∂ern und sp√§ter in Stavanger.  Riber war Kapellan an der Domkirche zu Bergen, als er 1540 von K√∂nig Christian¬†III. zum Superintendenten √ºber die F√§r√∂er berufen wurde, um die Reformation auf den F√§r√∂ern einzuf√ºhren. Er l√∂ste den letzten katholischen Bischof √Åmundur √ìlavsson ab und nahm dessen Sitz in Kirkjub√∏ur ein.  1556 oder 1557 verlie√ü er wieder die F√§r√∂er. Der sp√§tere Chronist Lucas Debes schreibt, dass Riber aus Furcht vor Piraten geflohen sei, nachdem diese den Bischofssitz in Kirkjub√∏ur √ºberfallen h√§tten. Absalon Pederss√∏n Beyer, der selbst an der Domkirche zu Bergen arbeitete, erw√§hnt aber nichts dergleichen, sondern berichtet, dass Riber nach Kopenhagen gefahren sei und um eine Entlassung aus dem Amt auf den F√§r√∂ern bat, weil er dort zu viele Widersacher und keine gro√üe Autorit√§t gehabt h√§tte.[1]  Der f√§r√∂ische Historiker Hans Jacob Debes h√§lt es f√ºr wahrscheinlich, dass sich die F√§ringer schwertaten, die neue Konfession anzunehmen. Ein Reformationsstreit, der √ºberall im d√§nisch-norwegischen Reich stattgefunden haben muss, denn Christian¬†III. verlangte in einem Rundschreiben an alle Superintendenten die Durchf√ºhrung spezieller Gebetstage, da ‚Äûsich S√ºnde und das B√∂se vermehren und Zeremonien nicht eingehalten werden‚Äú. Tats√§chlich sollen viele F√§ringer nur unwillig den Zehnten an die neue Kirche abgef√ºhrt und am katholischen Glauben festgehalten haben, zumal die Reformation den F√§r√∂ern von au√üen oktroyiert wurde.[1]  Als Jens Riber aus dem Amt schied, wurde das Bistum F√§r√∂er niedergelegt, und die F√§r√∂er wurden eine Propstei des Bistums Bj√∏rgvin (Bergen).  Riber wurde 1557 Bischof von Stavanger, obwohl er als charakterlich schwach und uninteressiert galt. Das Dansk biografisk leksikon spricht sogar vom ‚Äûgr√∂√üten Missgriff in der norwegischen Kirchengeschichte‚Äú.[2] Aus dieser Zeit sind keine herausragenden Dinge √ºberliefert, au√üer dass er 1564 zum Umbau des Doms von Stavanger beitrug, indem er unter anderem eine Sondersteuer zum Erhalt des heruntergekommenen Bauwerks durchsetzte.  1565 stellte man ihm den ambitionierten Gemeindepfarrer und Lehrer Jakob Matsson zur Seite, aber als dieser 1569 starb, verschlechterte sich die Zustand im Bistum noch einmal. 1571 griff der Lehnsherr von Bergenhus, Mads Skeel, ein und ernannte J√∏rgen Erikson (Erikss√∏n) zum Assistenten des nunmehr 90-j√§hrigen Riber, der sich aber weigerte, etwas von seinen Eink√ºnften an Erikson abzutreten. Eriksen kehrte unverrichteter Dinge nach Bergen zur√ºck und ging nach Kopenhagen, wo K√∂nig Friedrich¬†II. Bischof Riber endlich absetzte und Erikson als neuen Superintendenten von Stavanger einsetzte.  Jens Riber erfuhr von seiner Absetzung nichts mehr, weil er vorher verstarb.
English Bio:
Jens Gregersen Riber or Jens Gregoriussen Riber or Jens Gregerssøn Riber (* 1480 (?) In Ribe , Denmark , † August 9, 1571 in Stavanger , Norway ) was the first Lutheran bishop in the Faroe Islands and later in Stavanger.

Riber was Kapellan at the Domkirche zu Bergen when he was reigned in 1540 by King Christian III. was called to the Superintendent over the Faroe Islands to introduce the Reformation in the Faroe Islands . He replaced the last Catholic Bishop Ámundur Ólavsson and took his seat in Kirkjubøur .

In 1556 or 1557 he left again the Faroe Islands. The later chronicler Lucas Debes writes that Riber had fled out of fear of pirates after they had invaded the bishopric in Kirkjubøur. Absalon Pederssøn Beyer , who himself worked at the Dom church in Bergen, does not mention anything like that, but reports that Riber had gone to Copenhagen and asked for dismissal from office in the Faroes, because he had too many adversaries there and no great authority would have. [1]

The Faroese historian Hans Jacob Debes considers it likely that the Faroese struggled to accept the new denomination. A Reformation dispute that must have taken place everywhere in the Danish-Norwegian Empire, because Christian III. In a circular letter to all superintendents, it called for special prayer days to be held because "sin and evil multiply and ceremonies are not kept". In fact, many Faroese are said to have reluctantly removed tithes to the new church and held on to the Catholic faith, especially as the Reformation was imposed on the Faroes from outside. [1]

When Jens Riber left office, the diocese of Faroe Islands was laid down, and the Faroes became a provost of the Bishopric of Bjørgvin (Bergen) .

Riber became Bishop of Stavanger in 1557 , although he was considered weak and uninterested in character. The Dansk biografisk leksikon even speaks of the "biggest mistake in Norwegian church history". [2] From this time, no outstanding things are handed down, except that it in 1564 for the reconstruction of the Cathedral of Stavanger contributed, by imposing, among others, a special tax to maintain the run-down building.

In 1565, the ambitious parish pastor and teacher Jakob Matsson was placed at his side, but when he died in 1569, the situation in the bishopric deteriorated again. In 1571, the lord of Bergenhus , Mads Skeel, intervened and appointed Jørgen Erikson (Erikssøn) as assistant to the now 90-year-old Riber, who refused to relinquish some of his income to Erikson. Eriksen returned home to Bergen and went to Copenhagen, where King Frederick II finally deposed Bishop Riber and appointed Erikson as the new Stavanger superintendent.

Jens Riber learned nothing of his dismissal because he died before.

Name: Gustav Trolle
German Bio: Gustav Eriksson Trolle (* um 1488 in Bergkvara, Sm√•land; ‚Ä† 1535 auf der Insel F√ºnen, D√§nemark) war Sohn von Erik Arvidsson Trolle und schwedischer Erzbischof.  In der Entstehungsgeschichte des schwedischen Staates spielt Gustav Trolle eine kaum zu untersch√§tzende Rolle. Seine Unterst√ºtzung f√ºr den d√§nischen K√∂nig Christian II. f√ºhrte zu einem Konflikt mit dem schwedischen Reichsverweser Sten Sture dem J√ºngeren und schlie√ülich zu seiner Absetzung als Erzbischof. Dieser Umstand war entscheidend beim Stockholmer Blutbad, welches zun√§chst zwar ein herber R√ºckschlag f√ºr die Herausl√∂sung Schwedens aus der Kalmarer Union war, doch entscheidend die Einheit im Land st√§rkte. Gustav Vasa konnte mit Hilfe der Landbev√∂lkerung die D√§nen zur√ºckschlagen und legte sp√§ter als K√∂nig die Grundsteine f√ºr den schwedischen Staat.  Nach einigen Jahren Studium in K√∂ln und Rom wurde der Spro√ü der Familie Trolle 1513 zum Dekan von Link√∂ping ernannt. In Schweden war er einer der meist gebildeten und m√§chtigsten M√§nner seiner Zeit. Ein Jahr sp√§ter wurde er Erzbischof in Uppsala, wo er die Nachfolge von Jakob Ulvsson antrat.  Schweden befand sich seit 1397 in der Kalmarer Union, einem Bund, der die Staaten D√§nemark, Schweden und Norwegen unter einem K√∂nig vereinte. Jedes Land behielt dabei seinen eigenen Rat. Da ein gro√üer Teil Finnlands von Schweden regiert wurde, und Island zur norwegischen Krone geh√∂rte, umfasste die Kalmarer Union nahezu den gesamten Norden Europas. D√§nemark war hierbei die beherrschende Macht, w√§hrend die Union in Schweden nur von wenigen Adeligen getragen wurde. Aufst√§nde gegen die Union fanden immer wieder statt, wobei die D√§nen stets Truppen schickten, um die Ordnung wiederherzustellen.  Genau wie seine Vorg√§nger begann Trolle eine unionsfreundliche Politik. Schon 1515 geriet er deshalb in Konflikt mit dem schwedischen Reichsverweser Sten Sture dem J√ºngeren, der Schweden aus der Union herausl√∂sen wollte und vergeblich versuchte, Trolle auf seine Seite zu ziehen. Als klar war, dass Trolle dem d√§nischen K√∂nig Christian II. zuarbeiten w√ºrde, um die Union auch in Schweden zu st√§rken, lie√ü Sture Trolles Burg Almarest√§ket im Herbst 1516 belagern. Ein milit√§rischer Konflikt mit D√§nenk√∂nig Christian II. stand kurz bevor, so dass Sture, oder ‚ÄûHerr Sten‚Äú, wie er in der Sture-Chronik genannt wird, Trolle entmachten musste, bevor dieser Anh√§nger unter den Adeligen Schweden sammeln konnte. Als Sture Trolles Burg 1517 einnehmen konnte, lie√ü er Trolle verhaften. Die Burg wurde dem Erdboden gleichgemacht und Trolle auf Beschluss des St√§ndereichstags als Erzbischof abgesetzt. Dieser Beschluss, der von den Ratsmitgliedern per Siegel bekr√§ftigt wurde, diente sp√§ter als Beweismaterial beim Stockholmer Blutbad.  Die Invasion der D√§nen begann im Winter 1519‚Äì1520. Christian II. nahm die Entmachtung Trolles als Anlass, f√ºr die Wiederherstellung der Ordnung in Schweden zu sorgen, und marschierte mit seiner Armee in Schweden ein. Sein Heer bestand aus Berufssoldaten, S√∂ldnern, die er aus ganz Europa angeworben hatte und die erbarmungslos und kampferprobt waren. Stures M√§nner waren √ºberwiegend Bauernsoldaten, denen Steuerfreiheit versprochen wurde, wenn sie ihr Land verteidigten. Die Schlacht bei Bogesund, heute Ulricehamn am See √Ösundens im heutigen V√§sterg√∂tland, war eine f√ºr die D√§nen wie auch f√ºr die Schweden entscheidende Schlacht. Im Kampfverlauf wurde Reichsverwalter Sten Sture der J√ºngere von einer Kanonenkugel getroffen und starb wenig sp√§ter an seinen Verletzungen. D√§nenk√∂nig Christian II. ging siegreich aus der Schlacht hervor, und zog weiter bis nach Stockholm. Mit dem Tod Stures fehlte eine starke F√ºhrungsperson auf schwedischer Seite. Seine Frau Kristina Gyllenstierna √ºbernahm zwar das Kommando des Widerstands gegen die Union, aber es gelang ihr nicht, eine klare Einheit hinter sich zu vereinen. Schlie√ülich gelang es den D√§nen, Schweden im Herbst 1520 zu besetzen, wobei sich die Stadt Stockholm, unter der Leitung von Kristina Gyllenstierna, noch behaupten konnte. Christian II. lie√ü Trolle als Erzbischof wiedereinsetzen und erlie√ü eine Amnestie, die seinen Gegnern Straffreiheit garantierte, wenn er, Christian selbst, als Unionsk√∂nig anerkannt w√ºrde. Kristina Gyllenstierna und die am Widerstand beteiligten schwedischen Adeligen gingen auf das Amnestieangebot ein. Am 4. November 1520 wurde Christian II. durch Erzbischof Gustav Trolle in Stockholm zum K√∂nig von Schweden und damit zum K√∂nig der gesamten Union gekr√∂nt.  Es folgten Festlichkeiten, die drei Tage lang andauerten und an denen ebenfalls Kristina Gyllenstierna und Adelige des Widerstands teilnahmen. Aufgrund der ausgesprochenen Amnestie f√ºhlte man sich sicher. Am Abend des dritten Tages aber lie√ü der K√∂nig alle schwedischen Adeligen in einen Raum rufen und um sich versammeln. Die T√ºren wurden geschlossen und mit Wachen besetzt. In einem kurzen Prozess wurden die Anwesenden der Ketzerei beschuldigt, wobei Gustav Trolle eine entscheidende Rolle zukam: durch die Amnestie konnte niemand f√ºr den Widerstand gegen die Union verurteilt werden. Dies war durch den K√∂nig garantiert. Doch die Absetzung des Erzbischofs im Jahr 1517 war Ketzerei und ein Verbrechen gegen die Kirche, gegen das der K√∂nig keine Amnestie erlassen konnte. Der damalige Beschluss mit den Unterschriften der Ratsmitglieder wurde hervorgeholt und 94 Personen zum Tode verurteilt. Damit hatte Christian II. einen Weg gefunden, sich seiner Gegnerschaft mit einem Mal zu entledigen.  Die Hinrichtungen wurden kurz darauf auf dem Marktplatz (Stortorget) in Stockholm ausgef√ºhrt und dauerten 2 Tage. Man lie√ü die Leichen zun√§chst liegen, schaffte sie dann auf eine Bergkuppe auf der benachbarten Insel S√∂dermalm, wo sie in einem weithin sichtbaren Feuer verbrannt wurden. Sogar die Gebeine des ehemaligen Reichsverwalters Sten Sture des J√ºngeren wurden ausgegraben und mit den anderen Leichen verbrannt. Dieses Ereignis ging als das ‚ÄûStockholmer Blutbad‚Äú in die Geschichte ein.  Das Blutbad in Stockholm war Ausl√∂ser f√ºr einen gro√üangelegten Aufruhr in der schwedischen Bev√∂lkerung. Dem jungen Adeligen Gustav Vasa gelang es, eine Armee von Bauern hinter sich zu vereinen, die im Stande war, die D√§nen innerhalb von nur drei Jahren aus Schweden zu vertreiben. Vasa wurde 1523 in Str√§ngn√§s durch den Reichstag zum schwedischen K√∂nig ernannt und 1528 im Dom zu Uppsala gekr√∂nt.  Aufgrund der Geschehnisse erkannte Gustav Vasa Trolle nicht als Erzbischof an. Es kam zu Streitigkeiten mit dem Papst in Rom, der Trolle st√ºtzte. Infolgedessen wandte sich Vasa von der katholischen Kirche ab und leitete die Reformation in Schweden ein. Die Kirche wurde verstaatlicht, wobei ihr Besitz an den Staat √ºberging (Schwedische Staatskirche).  Bereits 1521 fl√ºchtete Trolle wegen Aufst√§nden in Sm√•land und Dalarna nach D√§nemark. Dort setzte er seinen Kampf an der Seite Christians fort. 1534 wurde er Bischof von F√ºnen in Odense. Bei der Schlacht von √òksnebjerg 1535 auf der Insel F√ºnen wurde er verwundet und starb in Gefangenschaft nach dem 11. Juni 1535 in Gottdorf.
English Bio:
Gustav Eriksson Trolls (* 1488 in Bergkvara , Småland , † 1535 on the island of Funen , Denmark) was the son of Erik Arvidsson trolls and Swedish archbishop.

In the genesis of the Swedish state Gustav Trolle plays a role that should not be underestimated. His support for the Danish King Christian II led to a conflict with the Swedish Governor Sten Sture the Younger and finally to his dismissal as Archbishop . This circumstance was decisive in the Stockholm bloodbath , which was initially a bitter setback for the separation of Sweden from the Kalmar Union , but significantly strengthened unity in the country. Gustave Vasa was able to fight back the Danes with the help of the rural population and later, as king, laid the foundations for the Swedish state.

After several years studying in Cologne and Rome, the scion of the Troll family was appointed in 1513 dean of Linköping . In Sweden he was one of the most educated and powerful men of his time. A year later he became archbishop in Uppsala , where he succeeded Jakob Ulvsson .

Sweden was in the Kalmar Union since 1397 , a federation that united the states of Denmark, Sweden and Norway under a king. Each country retained its own advice. Since much of Finland was governed by Sweden, and Iceland was part of the Norwegian krone, the Kalmar Union comprised almost the entire north of Europe. Denmark was the dominant power, while in Sweden only a few nobles supported the Union. Uprising against the Union took place again and again, with the Danes always sending troops to restore order.

Like its predecessors, Trolls began a Union-friendly policy. As early as 1515, he came into conflict with the Swedish administrator Sten Sture the Younger, who wanted to liberate Sweden from the Union and tried in vain to attract trolls to his side. When it became clear that Trolls would work for the Danish King Christian II to strengthen the Union in Sweden, Sture Trolles had the castle Almarestäket besieged in the fall of 1516. A military conflict with Danish king Christian II was imminent, leaving Sture, or "Mr. Sten," as he is in the Sture ChronicleTrolls had to be disempowered before this follower among the nobles could collect Sweden. When Sture Trolles castle in 1517 could take, he had arrested trolls. The castle was razed to the ground and trolls deposed as archbishop by decision of the estates day . This decision, by Council members per Seal reaffirmed served later as evidence in the Stockholm Bloodbath .

The invasion of the Danes began in the winter of 1519-1520. Christian II took the disempowerment of Trolles as an opportunity to restore order in Sweden and invaded his army in Sweden. His army consisted of professional soldiers, mercenaries whom he had recruited from all over Europe and who were merciless and battle-hardened. Sturgeon men were predominantly peasant soldiers who were promised tax exemption if they defended their land. The Battle of Bogesund , today Ulricehamn on the lake Åsundens in today's Västergötlandwas a decisive battle for the Danes as well as for the Swedes. In the course of the fight, Reich Administrator Sten Sture the Younger was hit by a cannonball and died shortly afterwards of his injuries. Danish king Christian II won the battle victoriously and moved on to Stockholm . With the death Stures missing a strong leader on the Swedish side. His wife Kristina GyllenstiernaAlthough taking the command of resistance to the Union, but she managed to unite a clear unity behind them. Eventually, the Danes succeeded in occupying Sweden in the fall of 1520, with the city of Stockholm, under the leadership of Kristina Gyllenstierna, still able to hold its own. Christian II had trolls reinstated as archbishop and issued an amnesty that guaranteed his opponents impunity if he, Christian himself, would be recognized as a Union King . Kristina Gyllenstierna and the Swedish nobles involved in the resistance went into the offer of amnesty. On November 4, 1520 Christian II was crowned King of Sweden by Archbishop Gustav Trolle in Stockholm and thus the king of the entire Union.


This was followed by festivities that lasted for three days and were also attended by Kristina Gyllenstierna and the nobles of the Resistance. Because of the pronounced amnesty you felt safe. On the evening of the third day, however, the king summoned all Swedish noblemen to a room and assembled. The doors were closed and staffed with guards. In a short process, those present became heresyaccused Gustav Trolle of decisive role: no one could be condemned by the amnesty for resisting the Union. This was guaranteed by the king. But the deposition of the archbishop in 1517 was heresy and a crime against the church, against which the king could not issue an amnesty. The then decision with the signatures of the council members was brought out and 94 people sentenced to death. Thus Christian II had found a way to get rid of his opponent suddenly.

The executions were carried out shortly thereafter in the market place ( Stortorget ) in Stockholm and lasted 2 days. The bodies were first left lying, then they were taken to a hilltop on the neighboring island of Södermalm , where they were burned in a fire that was visible from afar. Even the bones of former administrator Sten Sture the Younger were dug up and burned with the other bodies. This event went down in history as the " Stockholm Carnage ".

The bloodbath in Stockholm triggered a large-scale uprising in the Swedish population. The young nobleman Gustav Vasa managed to unite an army of peasants capable of expelling the Danes from Sweden within just three years. Vasa was appointed in 1523 in Strängnäs by the Reichstag to the Swedish king and crowned in 1528 in the cathedral of Uppsala .

Due to the events Gustav Vasa did not recognize trolls as archbishop. There were quarrels with the pope in Rome , who supported trolls. As a result, Vasa turned away from the Catholic Church and initiated the Reformation in Sweden. The church was nationalized, with her ownership passed to the state ( Swedish state church ).

Already in 1521 Troll fled to Denmark for riots in Småland and Dalarna . There he continued his fight at the side of Christian. In 1534 he became bishop of Funen in Odense . At the Battle of Øksnebjerg 1535 on the island of Funen he was wounded and died in captivity after June 11, 1535 in Gottdorf .

At the place where the aristocratic opponents of the Union were burned, stands today the St. Catherine's Church ( Katarina kyrka ). The church burnt down twice since its construction in 1695.
When trolls were deposed in 1517 as archbishop, councilor Bishop Brask hid a note under his seal. On this note was written: "For this sealing I was coerced and forced". Brask escaped his execution. The note saved his life.
Trolles Castle Almarestäket was built on a narrow spot in Lake Mälaren and guarded the entrance to important cities such as Sigtuna and Uppsala . The remains of the bishop's castle can still be seen on the grounds of the farm "Almarestäkets Herrgård". The nearby town Stäket north of Stockholm had in 2005 exactly 2093 inhabitants.
According to legend , on November 7 at midnight each night, the spirits of the 94 executed men are meeting in Stockholm's marketplace and dragging down the streets as a white fog.

Name: Jacob Madsen Vejle
German Bio: Jakob Madsen Vejle (auch: Jacob Matthias Villus, Jacon Matthiesen Viellg; * 24. Juli 1538 in Vejle; ‚Ä† 24. September 1606 in Odense) war ein d√§nischer evangelischer Bischof von F√ºnen.  Jakob Madsen war der Sohn des B√ºrgermeisters in Vejle Nils Madsen (‚Ä† 1539) und dessen Frau Ellen (Lene) Kristen (‚Ä† 1556), der Tochter des B√ºrgermeisters Nils Kristen in Varde.[1] Er hatte anf√§nglich die Schule seiner Heimatstadt besucht. 1548 wechselte er auf die Schule in Ribe, 1551 an die Schule in Odense, 1553 an die Schule Viborg und 1555 bezog er die Universit√§t Kopenhagen. Nach der Absolvierung seiner akademischen Grundausbildung reiste er 1561 an die Universit√§t L√∂wen und an die Universit√§t Paris. Seine Studien setzte er am 4. Dezember 1562[2] an der Universit√§t Wittenberg fort und erwarb sich dort am 10. August 1563 den akademischen Grad eines Magisters der Philosophie.[3]  Zur√ºckgekehrt nach D√§nemark war er zun√§chst an der Frauenkirche in Kopenhagen t√§tig, hielt Vorlesungen an der Universit√§t und wartete auf die Gelegenheit zu einer wirksameren Verwendung seiner Person im d√§nischen Staatsdienst. 1565 wurde er dann Rektor der Stadtschule in Ribe, √ºbernahm 1567 ein Pfarramt am Dom zu Ribe und erhielt 1568 ein Kanonikat im Domkapitel. Als theologischer Gutachter war er 1572 an den Hexenprozessen in Ribe beteiligt und sp√§ter an Regeln f√ºr Hochzeiten. 1587 wurde er zum Bischof von F√ºnen gew√§hlt. Jedoch w√ºnschte sich ihn seine Gemeinde wieder zur√ºck. Auf Intervention des K√∂nigs wurde er 1588 in der Kirche St. Knud in Odense von seinem Vetter Bischof Hans Laugesen aus Ribe geweiht. Er beteiligte sich an der Beseitigung katholischer Relikte in seinem Bistum und verbot 1595 die Konkordienformel. 1596 nahm er an der feierlichen Kr√∂nung Christians¬†IV. teil.  Aus seiner am 18. Oktober 1566 geschlossenen Ehe mit Karen (* um 1548; ‚Ä† 4. Mai 1615), der Tochter des Ratmanns in Ribe Jens Bagge, sind 13. Kinder hervorgegangen. Bekannt sind:
English Bio:
Jakob Madsen Vejle (also: Jacob Matthias Villus, Jacon Matthiesen Viellg , born July 24, 1538 in Vejle , † September 24, 1606 in Odense ) was a Danish Protestant bishop of Funen .

Jakob Madsen was the son of the mayor in Vejle Nils Madsen († 1539) and his wife Ellen (Lene) Kristen († 1556), the daughter of the mayor Nils Kristen in Varde . [1] He had initially attended school in his hometown. In 1548 he moved to the school in Ribe , 1551 to the school in Odense , 1553 to the Viborg school and 1555 he moved to the University of Copenhagen . After completing his academic education in 1561 he traveled to the University of Louvain and to the University of Paris . He continued his studies on 4 December 1562 [2] at the University of WittenbergOn August 10, 1563, he obtained the academic degree of Master of Philosophy there. [3]

Returning to Denmark, he first worked at the Frauenkirche in Copenhagen, held lectures at the university and waited for the opportunity to use his person more effectively in the Danish civil service. In 1565 he became rector of the city school in Ribe, took over in 1567 a parish office at the Cathedral of Ribe and received in 1568 a canon in the cathedral chapter . As a theological expert, he was involved in 1572 in the witch trials in Ribe and later on rules for weddings. In 1587 he was elected Bishop of Funen. However, his community wished him back. At the king's intervention, he was bishop in 1588 in the church of St. Knud in Odense by his cousinHans Laugesen from Ribe consecrated. He participated in the removal of Catholic relics in his diocese and banned in 1595 the Konkordienformel . In 1596 he took part in the solemn coronation of Christian IV .

Name: Thomas Kingo
German Bio: Thomas Hansen Kingo (* 15. Dezember 1634 in Slangerup Kommune; ‚Ä† 14. Oktober 1703 in Odense) war ein d√§nischer lutherischer Bischof und Dichter von Kirchenliedern, den sogenannten Kingopsalmen.  Thomas Kingo ist Sohn von Karen S√∏rensdatter und des Webers Hans Thomsen Kingo, dessen Vorfahren aus Schottland kamen.[1] Obwohl aus einfachen Verh√§ltnissen stammend, erm√∂glichten sie ihrem Sohn den Schulbesuch in Slangerup und sp√§ter in Frederiksborg, wo er unter anderem Literaturgeschichte lernte und 1654 sein Abitur machte. 1658 folgte das Theologieexamen.  Zun√§chst war er dann Hauslehrer in Frederiksborg und ab 1659 auf dem Gut Vedbygaard, wo er seine ersten Gedichte schrieb. Im D√§nischen Biografischen Lexikon (1887‚Äì1905) wird hervorgehoben, dass der Humor und die Lebensn√§he dieser Gedichte ungew√∂hnlich f√ºr ihre Zeit waren - aber auch f√ºr sein sp√§teres weltliches Werk.[2]  1661 wurde Thomas Kingo Hilfspfarrer und 1668 schlie√ülich Gemeindepfarrer in seinem Geburtsort Slangerup. Dort heiratete er die Pfarrerstochter Sille Balkenborg aus Norwegen, die drei T√∂chter aus vorheriger Ehe hatte. Die Ehe blieb kinderlos und seine Frau verstarb bereits 1670. Ihr widmete er die Weise Chrysillis, du min Verdens Guld (Chrysillis, du mein Gold der Welt). Etwa vier Jahre sp√§ter heiratete er die Witwe seines Verwalters, Johanne Laurdsdatter Lund, die 13 Jahre √§lter war als er. Diese Ehe sollte 20 Jahre dauern, wird aber nicht als gl√ºcklich beschrieben, was sein d√§nischer Biograf im 19. Jahrhundert allerdings als normal f√ºr die damalige Zeit beschreibt, wo noch nicht so viel Wert auf Ehen aus Liebe gelegt wurde.  In jenen Jahren geriet er in erbitterten Konflikt mit dem satirischen Dichter Jacob Worm. Beide schrieben √ºbereinander Schm√§hverse, wovon Kingos Kalot das bekannteste Gedicht ist. Es erschien damals anonym. Daneben schuf er in seiner Zeit als Gemeindepfarrer eine ganze Reihe an Gedichten, die sich in drei Kategorien einteilen lassen:  Das D√§nische Biografische Lexikon bezeichnet seine weltliche Dichtung als nicht sonderlich √ºberragend, wo sich nur selten der Nebel der Geschmacklosigkeit lichtet und dichterische Inspiration zum Vorschein kommt.[3] Seine patriotischen Verse besch√§ftigen sich meist mit der Verherrlichung des absolutistischen Herrschers Christian¬†V., was aber zu jener Zeit nicht nur in D√§nemark √ºblich war. Diese Werke stehen unter deutlichem Einfluss aus Deutschland.  Kingos geistliche Dichtung (im D√§nischen nennt man sie Psalmendichtung) hingegen genie√üt einen weit h√∂heren Stellenwert. Hier ging er f√ºr seine Zeit neue Wege, die von einer gewissen Stagnation nach der Reformation (in D√§nemark 1536) gepr√§gt war. Obwohl er als t√ºchtiger Pfarrer galt, so war dieses lebendige Werk wohl ausschlaggebend daf√ºr, dass er 1677 zum Bischof von F√ºnen ernannt wurde. 1679 folgte die Aufnahme Kingos in den Adelsstand. 1682 wurde er Doktor der Theologie.  1683 bekam er vom K√∂nig den Auftrag, ein neues Gesangbuch herauszugeben, da das bisherige von Hans Thomiss√∏n (1569) als nicht mehr zeitgem√§√ü f√ºr den Geschmack der Zeit galt. Nach sechs Jahren Arbeit erschien der erste Teil (Vinterparten ‚Äì Winterteil) des Danmarks og Norges Kirke forordnede Salmebog (Verordnetes Gesangbuch f√ºr die Kirche D√§nemarks und Norwegens). Hierzu hatte Kingo an seinem Bischofssitz eine eigene Druckerei eingerichtet. Das Buch enth√§lt 267 Lieder f√ºr das Kirchenjahr zwischen dem 1. Advent und Ostern, die H√§lfte davon Kingos eigene Werke. Allerdings kam es nicht zur erhofften Auslieferung an alle Gemeinden im K√∂nigreich. Stattdessen erschien 1699 das Den Forordnede Kirkepsalmebog, welches immerhin noch 85 Kingopsalmen enthielt. Viele von ihnen stehen heute noch in den Gesangb√ºchern der d√§nischen und norwegischen Volkskirche und sind wie Grundtvigs Kirchenlieder Bestandteil des nordischen geistlichen Erbes.  Bereits 1694 verstarb seine Frau Johanne. Im Alter von 60 Jahren heiratete Kingo erneut. Diesmal eine 30 Jahre j√ºngere Frau, Birgitte Balslev, Arzttochter aus Odense. Diese Ehe wird als gl√ºcklich beschrieben, blieb aber kinderlos.  Thomas Kingo litt in seinen letzten Jahren an Steinen und Wundrose. Er starb 1703 im Alter von 68 Jahren. Seine von Thomas Quellinus gestaltetes Grabkapelle befindet sich in der Fraugde Kirke bei Odense.  W√§hrend Kingos Werk als der H√∂hepunkt der d√§nischen Barockdichtung gilt, sind seine Kirchenlieder in D√§nemark und Norwegen heute noch Teil der Gesangb√ºcher, und insbesondere auf den F√§r√∂ern sind sie lebendiger Teil des dortigen Kulturerbes ‚Äì ein eigenst√§ndiges Musikgenre. In Odense und Slangerup erinnern Denkm√§ler und Epitaphien (so von Thomas Quellinus) an den Dichter, doch sein gr√∂√ütes Denkmal sind die Psalmen, die heute in Skandinavien fortleben.  Du, o Herr, wei√üt am besten, wessen ich bedarf, auch das Gl√ºck liegt in deinen H√§nden. Und was mir in jederlei Weise zum Besten dient, siehst du ja bereits; meine Seele, was willst du mehr? Lass nur Gott walten!  (Thomas Kingo: Nu rinder solen op af √∏sterlide 1674)  Auf den F√§r√∂ern hat Kingos Kirchengesangbuch von 1699 eine Bedeutung erlangt, die heute noch sp√ºrbar ist. Auf den Kingopsalmen basierend, entwickelte sich ein eigenes Genre der f√§r√∂ischen Musik, die bis ins 19. Jahrhundert ohne Begleitung von Instrumenten wie der Kirchenorgel auskam, die erst nach dem Bau der f√§r√∂ischen Holzkirchen langsam Einzug hielten. Der deutsche F√§r√∂er-Reisende Carl Julian von Graba schrieb 1828 in seinem Tagebuch, gef√ºhrt auf einer Reise nach Far√∂ zu den Kingoliedern der F√§ringer:  ‚Äûder Gesang war das F√ºrchterlichste, was ich je in meinem Leben geh√∂rt habe; jeder br√ºllt den erstbesten Ton, der ihm in den Sinn kommt.‚Äú  An der Bedeutung der Lieder √§ndert das freilich ebenso wenig, wie an der Hochachtung die Graba an anderer Stelle vor dem hohen geistlichen Bildungsniveau des einfachen Volkes hatte.  Um 1900 verloren die Kingopsalmen ihre alles beherrschende Stellung im geistlichen Leben der F√§ringer, wurden aber lokal weiterhin als das Kirchenliedgut lebendig gehalten.  Bekannt ist in diesem Zusammenhang die Gemeinde von Tj√∏rnuv√≠k im √§u√üersten Norden der Insel Streymoy, wo erst 1983 eine Orgel eingef√ºhrt wurde. √úber fast drei Jahrhunderte verlie√ü man sich hier in erster Linie auf Kingo. Der Kingo-Chor des Dorfes spielte eine zentrale Rolle bei dem Projekt des Haus des Nordens, 1988 die f√§r√∂ische Kingo-Gesangstradition zu registrieren. Bereits 1984 erschien die Suite Kingol√∏g von Kristian Blak, die das alte Liedgut verschiedener D√∂rfer zur Grundlage hatte.  Die Kingo-Gruppe aus Tj√∏rnuv√≠k trat nicht nur auf dem nationalen Kunstfestival 2001 auf, sondern wurde im Kingojahr 2003 vom Kopenhagener Bischof zu den dortigen Feierlichkeiten eingeladen. Eiv√∏r P√°lsd√≥ttir sorgte f√ºr moderne Interpretationen der Kingopssalmen, die seit 2003 auch als wichtiger Bestandteil des Musikunterrichts auf den F√§r√∂ern genannt werden. Das damalige nationale Kunstfestival Listastevna F√∏roya stand unter dem Motto Kingos, und es wurden in verschiedenen Dorfkirchen spezielle Kingo-Gottesdienste abgehalten.  Die originalen Kingogesangb√ºcher finden sich im Archiv der Landesbibliothek der F√§r√∂er, werden aber auch im Historischen Museum ausgestellt. Im Gesangbuch der F√§r√∂ischen Volkskirche finden sich 31 Kingopsalmen, darunter einer noch in altem D√§nisch, w√§hrend alle anderen ins F√§r√∂ische √ºbersetzt wurden.
English Bio:
Thomas Hansen Kingo (born December 15, 1634 in Slangerup Commune , † October 14, 1703 in Odense ) was a Danish Lutheran bishop and poet of hymns , the so-called Kingopsalmen .

Thomas Kingo is the son of Karen Sørensdatter and the weaver Hans Thomsen Kingo, whose ancestors came from Scotland. [1] Although coming from a humble background, she allowed her son to school in Slangerup and later in Frederiksborg , where he, among other literary history learned and in 1654 completed his schooling. 1658 followed the theology exam .

He was then a private tutor in Frederiksborg and from 1659 on the estate Vedbygaard, where he wrote his first poems . In the Danish Biographical Encyclopedia (1887-1905) it is emphasized that the humor and closeness of these poems were unusual for their time - but also for his later secular work . [2]

1661 Thomas Kingo auxiliary pastor and 1668 finally parish priest in his birthplace Slangerup. There he married the pastor's daughter Sille Balkenborg from Norway, who had three daughters from previous marriage. The marriage remained childless and his wife died in 1670. To her he dedicated the sage Chrysillis, you min Verden's Guld (Chrysillis, you my gold of the world). About four years later, he married the widow of his steward, Johanne Laurdsdatter Lund, 13 years his senior. This marriage was to last 20 years, but is not described as happy, which his Danish biographer in the 19th century, however, describes as normal for that time, where not so much emphasis was placed on marriages out of love.

In those years he came into fierce conflict with the satirical poet Jacob Worm . Both wrote one above the other abusive verses, of which Kingos Kalot is the most famous poem. It appeared anonymous then. In addition, he created in his time as parish priest a number of poems, which can be divided into three categories:

love poems
Homeland poems
Spiritual poetry
The Danish Biographical Encyclopedia describes its secular poetry as not particularly outstanding, where seldom does the fog of tastelessness clear and poetic inspiration emerge . [3] His patriotic verses dealing mostly with the glorification of the absolutist ruler Christian V. , but this was common at that time, not only in Denmark. These works are under significant influence from Germany.

Kingo's spiritual poetry (in Danish , it is called the psalm seal ), however, enjoys a far higher status. Here he went for his time new ways, which was marked by a certain stagnation after the Reformation (in Denmark in 1536). Although he was considered a good pastor, this lively work was probably decisive for the fact that he was appointed Bishop of Funen in 1677 . 1679 followed the inclusion Kingos in the peerage. In 1682 he became a doctor of theology.

In 1683 he was commissioned by the king to publish a new hymn book, as the previous one by Hans Thomissøn (1569) was no longer up to date for the taste of the time. After six years of work, the first part ( Vinterparten - winter part) of the Danmarks og Norges Kirke forordnede Salmebog ( Decree Hymnal for the Church of Denmark and Norway) appeared. For this Kingo had set up his own printing house at his bishopric. The book contains 267 songs for the church year between the 1st of Advent and Easter, half of which are Kingos own works. However, it did not come to the hoped-for extradition to all communities in the kingdom. Instead, appeared in 1699 Den Forordnede Kirkepsalmebog , which still contained 85 Kingopsalmen . Many of them are still in the hymnbooks of the Danish and Norwegian national churches and like Grundtvig's hymns are part of the Nordic spiritual heritage.

Already in 1694 his wife Johanne died. At age 60, Kingo remarried. This time a 30 years younger woman, Birgitte Balslev, doctor's daughter from Odense. This marriage is described as happy, but remained childless.

Thomas Kingo suffered in his last years of stones and Wundrose . He died in 1703 at the age of 68 years. His grave chapel designed by Thomas Quellinus is located in Fraugde Kirke near Odense .

While Kingo's work is regarded as the culmination of the Danish baroque poetry , his hymns in Denmark and Norway are still part of the hymnbooks today, and especially in the Faroe Islands they are a living part of the local heritage - an independent musical genre. In Odense and Slangerup remind monuments and epitaphs (as by Thomas Quellinus ) to the poet, but his greatest monument are the psalms that live today in Scandinavia.

You, O Lord, know best what I need, 
also happiness is in your hands. 
And what you do in every way for the best, 
you already see; my soul, what more do you want? 
Just let God do it!

(Thomas Kingo: Nu rinder solen op af østerlide 1674)

In the Faeroe Islands Kingos Hymnal of 1699 has gained importance, which is still noticeable today. Based on the Kingopsalmen, developed a separate genre of Faroese music , which until the 19th Century without accompaniment of instruments such as the church organ got along, which slowly after the construction of the Faroese wooden churches were introduced. The German Faroese traveler Carl Julian von Graba wrote in his diary in 1828 , led on a trip to Faroe to the Kingolieder the Faroese:

"The singing was the most dreadful thing I have ever heard in my life; Everyone roars the first sound that comes to mind. "

Of course, this does not change the meaning of the songs, nor does Graba have any respect for the high spiritual level of education of the common people.

Around 1900, the Kingopsalmen lost their dominant position in the religious life of the Faroese , but were still locally kept alive as the hymn.

Known in this context is the community of Tjørnuvík in the extreme north of the island Streymoy , where only in 1983 an organ was introduced. For almost three centuries, people relied primarily on Kingo. The village's Kingo Choir played a pivotal role in the House of the North Project's 1988 record of the Faroese Kingo vocal tradition. As early as 1984, the Suite Kingoløg by Kristian Blak , which had the old songs of various villages as a basis.

The Kingo group from Tjørnuvík not only performed at the national art festival in 2001, but was also invited to the festivities by the Copenhagen bishop in 2003 . Eivør Pálsdóttir provided modern interpretations of the Kingopssalmen, which since 2003 have also been mentioned as an important part of music education in the Faroe Islands. Listastevna Føroya, the national art festival of the time, was themed Kingos, and special Kingo services were held in various village churches.

The original kongo singing books can be found in the archives of the Faroese National Library , but are also exhibited in the Historical Museum . In the hymnbook of the Faroese national church there are 31 Kingopsalmen, including one in old Danish, while all others were translated into Faroese .

Die Christianisierung war durch die mitgebrachten irischen Sklaven und deren Einfluss eingeleitet und durch die Aussendung von Missionaren im 10. Jahrhundert verst√§rkt worden.  √çsleifur Gissurarson, der Sohn von √û√≥rd√≠s √û√≥roddsd√≥ttir und Gissur Teitsson aus dem Mosfellingar-Clan erhielt seine kirchliche Ausbildung im ostwestf√§lischen Herford und wurde 1056 vom Bremer Erzbischof Adalbert zum ersten Bischof von Island und Gr√∂nland geweiht.[1]  Er lie√ü sich auf dem s√ºdisl√§ndischen Gut Sk√°lholt nieder, wo seine Familie Grund besa√ü, und gr√ºndete dort auch die erste isl√§ndische Schule. English Bio:
Ísleifur Gissurarson (* 1006 , † July 5, 1080 ) was the first bishop of Iceland and Greenland .

In 1000, the then Republic of Iceland took over Christianity by parliamentary decision as state religion. The Christianization was initiated by the brought along Irish slaves and their influence and strengthened by the sending of missionaries in the 10th century.

Ísleifur Gissurarson, the son of _órdís _óroddsdóttir and Gissur Teitsson from the Mosfellingar -Clan received his ecclesiastical training in East Westphalian Herford and was consecrated in 1056 by the Archbishop of Bremen Adalbert to the first bishop of Iceland and Greenland . [1]

He settled in Skálholt in the south of Iceland , where his family owned land, and founded the first Icelandic school there. At the same time he also took over the godhood of his father.

His wife was Dalla _orvaldsdóttir . With this he had three sons, _orvaldur , Teitur and Gissur , who took over after the death of his father's episcopate. One of his students was Jón Ögmundarson , who later served as Bishop of Hólar .

When Ísleifur died in Skálholt on July 5, 1080, he had held the episcopal see there for 24 years. [2]

His son Gissur Ísleifsson followed him in the office.

Name: Eirikur Gn√∫psson Eirik Gnuppson verschollen, m√∂glicherweise an der Ostk√ºste Amerikas, dem von den Wikingern entdeckten ‚ÄûVinland‚Äú
